pros: Interesting business challenges and very smart people
cons: Decision making can be slow at times

pros: Work from home opportunity, reasonable work hours
cons: Difficult career mobility within Company

pros: Nice people and good work life balance
cons: Compensation is low, too much low value added work

review_title: Average workplace with potential if under the right manager
pros: Ability to move within company
cons: Limited visibility to senior management

pros: Location is good. High profile name. Global company. Some People are able to use the flexible work policy, but it varies. Not much else to say here.
cons: Not enough women in leadership roles or in middle management. Bureaucratic, old systems, and “a dinosaur” as the other reviews say. Some people have been here very long time so the culture is stuck. Communication is poor within and across departments. This impacts US but also when trying to work with global workforce and offshore teams. Managers can be unnecessarily tough on staff (as others commented). There is more than average amount of petty complaining and office politics.

review_title: Collegial environment but slow to move up
pros: Colleagues are nice and helpful.
cons: Slow to move up. Too much hierarchy in the company.

pros: Learn a ton, really talented team.
cons: Management can be ruthless and overwork staff. Very stringent structure

pros: Profitable business with great business model; good benefits; on face value, great diversity programs
cons: Depends on which group you work in... Shared Services area is managed by senior management only interested in empire building... if you are working in Transformation project area, forget about work-life balance... project mismanagement will ensure you work like a dog... if you work in Operations area, you will not have enough resources to deliver quality product or service...
advice_to_mgmt:
Executive management should ensure that senior management actually follow up on cultural values involving inter team collaboration...

Not aligning bottom line goals with cultural values professed will result in bottom line goals corrupting cultural values... Corporate culture is what you do, not what you say...

pros: Smart people across various lines of business.
cons: Changing corporate culture as company grows.

pros: Plenty of information to read and learn
cons: The culture and senior management's action don't align.

pros: Flexible working hours and decent collegues
cons: No program or product strategy on any key transformation projects. Senior managers only like yes men. The work environment is very toxic
advice_to_mgmt: There is a lot of talent in the company that is under utilized. Listen to people who you disagree with too.

pros: Overtime Eligible, Work/Life Balance is good (9-5)
cons: Upward movement is extremely limited, promotions are not earned and given they are applied for. Communication from superiors is very fragmented and it seems the position is either getting left behind or replaced. You will pigeon-hole yourself if you take a role as an FDA. Skills are not very transferable and management is not very motivating. Superiors do not have the highest level of educational background either. Moody's is the little brother of the financial services industry that banks are forced to play with due to the government. 401k Matching program is weak as is the Stock Purchase plan...does not compete with other similar firms.

pros: job security, comfortable office corporate life
cons: office politics, bureaucracy, out of date technology, excessive compliance rules that's detrimental in just being able to be productive
advice_to_mgmt: My advice won't matter. The company is comparable to a giant dinosaur that'll continue to chug along

pros: Interesting work, work-life balance, women at senior levels
cons: Low pay, slow to promote, political

review_title: Great work/life balance, but no frills
pros: People: overall, smart and hardworking. Work/life balance: great. Perks: basic, but very reasonable.
cons: Regulations imposed after the recession caused a deepening of policy of procedures that seemed to drop morale. There's more admin tasks that have to be done. Harder to get promoted, little meritocracy. Very few social activities.

pros: Good environment and nice place to grow
cons: Not so high payments

pros: This is for people looking for administrative assistant roles within the company....great work/life balance (my official hours are 9-5, rare paid OT), can work remotely, nice people, cafeteria/Starbucks coffee bar on site, good health/dental, days off/early dismissals.
cons: Days can get pretty boring (depending on who/what team one is supporting), not a lot of career mobility. There are a few admins here who have gone on to other roles within the company, but for the most part this is the perfect job for those who just want a stable job that pays for their lives outside the office - family, vacation, hobbies, etc. Not the place to make tons of money and work your way up the ladder.
advice_to_mgmt: Pay more attention to administrative assistants - associate analysts, mid-level women have programs designed to move them up the career ladder, please do something similar for admins that don't want to be pigeonholed into one thing.

pros: Large downtown nyc rating agency
cons: You’re just a number not a person

pros: smart people and great work
cons: some politics to manage at headquarters

pros: Great work life balance and pretty good pay for how laid back it is and very good exit opportunities
cons:
Like most large places, very political to move up. The company used to have the people you actually work with have more say in your advancement, but recently, the company introduced middle managers who don't see/understand your work as much, but have a large say in your advancement, so sucking up matters way more than performance.
Also, due to poor management of handling regulatory compliance, there are teams of people who exist to try and catch you not checking the right box so you can get your bonus taken away. It never happened to me, but it did to people I know and living in fear of the compliance cops isn't fun. Also, lots of lifers work here, so get used to unintentional caps lock and constant whining about how they don't understand the electric typing box.
advice_to_mgmt: The middle managers are pointless, compliance checkers create a culture of fear, you spend way too much on rent when you should have people work at home more like your competitors do (cough, s&p), and you're not that progressive so please top telling us that you are when the composition of your c suite and board looks like any other old fortune 500. Thank you for the pay adjustment though to pay market rates. I liked that.

review_title: Great for exposure to projects and senior leaders
pros: A great learning experience, plethora of knowledge to soak up and you really get involved with projects and individuals
cons: No work life balance , but I realize that depends on the department you work in. Being in a shared service environment you would think we wouldn’t work long hours and unnecessary hours at that.
advice_to_mgmt: Not sure how you have receive the working mother’s award when flexibility and work life balance doesn’t apply to people below VP.

pros: pay benefit insurance coworkers exposure
cons: work life balance, time off

pros: Good location, good prescription and medical coverage.
cons: Poor work life balance, organizationally in Flux, many male immigrant employees who do not respect women in the workplace.
advice_to_mgmt: Stop talking the talk and start walking the walk. Many older, foreign born men in the company have strongly held, and loudly voiced anti - woman in the workplace views. It is Extremely hard to be a woman and get ahead in this culture.

review_title: Overall a very employee development-focused company
pros:
Work life balance is valued
Great benefits package
Above-average opportunities for employee development
cons: Upward mobility takes extensive time

review_title: HR team specific review - Hope they are fixing the HR team culture in the US
pros: Company itself has solid business leadership, and good outlook, work/life balance, smart & talented people.
cons: HR transformation 2014 was a disaster, high turnover and poor, non-transparent leaders who did not understand the value of retaining HR talent. Politics at play, nobody was told why people were being “let go”, toxic individuals — extremely bad environment that made good people leave. I’ve heard things didn’t exactly get better after.
advice_to_mgmt: For such a well-branded global firm, key parts of HR were embarrassingly poorly run in terms of basic management and treatment of employees . I was shocked and saddened at the negative culture. I hope lessons have been learned the past few years, and the necessary improvements made. The HR work culture needs to be improved. I know you there is the leadership talent to do it. Good luck.

pros: flexible work place and worklife balance
cons: lack of learning technical skills

pros: You can earn a lot of responsibility early
cons: Pay. Wide skill range in coworkers at the associate analyst level- a lot of dead weight.

pros: The flexibility and the benefit s are great
cons: There is t a lot of room for growth

review_title: Good for a short term job
pros:
Work life balance is is good
Benefits are good
cons:
If you stay in your position for longer than a few years without a promotion, your chances of promotion or being interviewed for other positions within the company are non existent
New RRS team setup brings in more management and less transparency
Technology is more of a hindrance than a help in day to day work life
